intro: Halophila australis, commonly known as the Australian sea horse grass, is a marine flowering plant found in shallow coastal waters of the Indo-Pacific region. It belongs to the family Hydrocharitaceae and is characterized by its dense, underwater growth forming mats on sandy or muddy substrates. The plant has slender, branching stems and small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically borne in clusters. It plays a vital role in stabilizing sediments and providing habitat for various marine organisms. Halophila australis is adapted to saline environments and contributes to the ecological balance of coastal ecosystems.
